justifications: May said the U.K. and EU 'can do so much better' than a CETA-style trade agreement since they were beginning from the 'unprecedented position' of sharing a body of rules and regulations.

Monique Ebell, formerly of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, stressed that even with an agreement in place, non-tariff barriers were likely to be a significant drag on Britain's trade with the EU.
Free trade deals also struggle to rein in non-tariff barriers.
If Britain and the EU were not able to agree their relationship, they would have had to revert to WTO terms.
